projects.title: SmartRetry — Headless Fintech Marketing Platform
projects.summary: Architected and delivered a production-grade fintech marketing platform using a headless CMS and modular frontend system, built for rapid iteration, maintainability, and long-term scalability.

overview.scope: A modular fintech marketing platform with CMS-driven directories, glossary, FAQ systems, structured content modules, and interactive UX components.
overview.responsibility: Frontend architecture, CMS integration, structured module development, animation implementation, and production-ready feature delivery.

projects.problem: The platform required frequent content updates, structured SEO-driven modules, and complex interactive sections while maintaining performance and developer velocity in a startup environment. The challenge was balancing animation-heavy UX with clean architecture and long-term maintainability.
constraints: Heavy animation requirements without degrading performance
Headless CMS limitations and content modeling complexity
projects.approach: I designed the platform around a modular, component-driven architecture using Next.js App Router and TypeScript to ensure scalability and clarity. Content was modeled in WordPress as structured post types and consumed via REST endpoints. Interactive and animated sections were implemented using controlled client components to prevent unnecessary re-renders, prioritizing performance and maintainability over visual shortcuts.

architecture.frontend: Next.js 15 App Router + TypeScript + Tailwind CSS
architecture.cms: Headless WordPress with structured post types and ACF
architecture.data: REST-based CMS integration with typed fetch layers

execution: Implemented CMS-driven payment provider directory with filtering and search
Built modular FAQ and glossary systems mirroring structured blog architecture
Developed scroll-driven 'How It Works' section using IntersectionObserver and controlled Lottie animation state
Structured type-safe data fetching layers for WordPress REST integration
Designed reusable UI components for consistent spacing, theming, and layout fidelity
Maintained strict ESLint and TypeScript standards to prevent architectural drift
outcomes: Enabled rapid iteration through structured CMS-driven modules
Reduced developer dependency for routine content updates
Maintained performance despite animation-heavy UX requirements
Delivered scalable frontend architecture suitable for future expansion
projects.reflection: This project reinforced the importance of structuring content models correctly early, as CMS design decisions directly affect frontend complexity. It also highlighted the tradeoff between visual interactivity and architectural clarity — animation must serve usability, not compromise maintainability.

projects.title: SOCA — AI-Powered Task Management System
projects.summary: A full-stack task management web application that leverages generative AI to automatically break complex tasks into actionable subtasks, reducing cognitive overload and improving execution clarity.

heroImage.alt: SOCA AI-powered task management system preview

overview.scope: A web-based task management system that allows users to create, manage, and complete daily tasks, enhanced with AI-powered subtask generation.
overview.responsibility: End-to-end architecture, database design, authentication flow, AI integration, and frontend implementation.

projects.problem: Users often struggle to execute large or vague tasks because they lack structure and clarity. Traditional task managers rely entirely on manual task breakdown, which can increase friction and procrastination.
constraints: API usage limits and response latency from AI providers
Need to maintain responsive UI while handling async AI calls
Authentication and data isolation per user
projects.approach: I designed SOCA as a structured task manager first, then layered AI capabilities on top. The system stores core tasks in a relational database and, upon user request, calls the generative API to intelligently chunk large tasks into smaller actionable subtasks. I prioritized keeping AI generation optional and non-blocking to maintain usability even if external API calls fail.
execution: Designed relational database schema for users, tasks, and subtasks
Implemented secure user authentication with Gmail login integration
Built full CRUD functionality for tasks (create, edit, delete, mark as complete)
Integrated Cohere API and LLaMA-based models for automated subtask generation
Handled asynchronous AI responses and dynamically updated UI without full page reload
Ensured user-level task isolation and secure data handling
outcomes: Reduced cognitive load by automatically converting large goals into manageable subtasks
Improved task clarity and execution structure for end users
Demonstrated integration of generative AI within a traditional PHP full-stack environment
Built a functional AI-assisted productivity system from scratch
projects.reflection: If extending SOCA further, I would refactor the architecture into a more modern framework (e.g., Next.js + API layer), implement rate-limiting and caching for AI responses, and introduce smarter prioritization algorithms based on task metadata.

projects.title: Library Course-Based Computer Usage Monitoring System
projects.summary: Designed and built a desktop monitoring system that tracked computer usage by enrolled course, improving resource visibility and administrative efficiency within a university library environment.

overview.scope: A desktop-based monitoring system that tracked active computer users by academic course and generated structured usage reports for administrative analysis.
overview.responsibility: System design, UI implementation, data modeling, reporting logic, and on-site support.

projects.problem: The library lacked structured visibility into computer usage patterns across different academic courses. Monitoring was manual, time-consuming, and prone to record inaccuracies, limiting the administration’s ability to allocate resources effectively.
constraints: Non-technical staff as primary system users
Minimal tolerance for system downtime during operating hours
projects.approach: I approached the project by first mapping the real-world workflow of library staff and identifying bottlenecks in data recording and reporting. The system was designed to simplify user registration tracking while automatically structuring data for export. Usability and clarity were prioritized over technical complexity to ensure seamless adoption by non-technical users.

architecture.deployment: Local desktop deployment within library environment

execution: Designed user interface tailored for quick staff input and monitoring
Implemented structured tracking of users categorized by academic course
Built automated Excel export functionality using Pandas for reporting
Optimized data handling to reduce manual encoding and errors
Provided on-site software and hardware troubleshooting support
outcomes: Improved visibility into departmental computer usage trends
Reduced manual reporting workload for library staff
Increased record accuracy through structured data capture
Delivered a practical internal system aligned with operational workflows
projects.reflection: This project reinforced the importance of aligning technical solutions with real-world operational processes. Designing for non-technical users required clarity and restraint — simplicity proved more valuable than adding advanced features.
